div.head: Of the State of Nature in the Digital Commonwealth

opener.signed: By THOMAS HOBBES of Malmesbury, Author of that Most Renowned Treatise LEVIATHAN, or The Matter, Forme and Power of a COMMON-WEALTH Ecclesiasticall and Civil

list.head: A Table of the Principal Contents
list.item:
Of the State of Nature in the Digital Commonwealth
Wherein is demonstrated how the ancient state of war is transformed into digital conflict
That the digital life remains brutish though no longer solitary
Concerning the new currencies of attention and validation

Of the Nature of Posts and the Social Contract
How men's thoughts are now confined to 280 characters
Of the surrender of privacy to the Algorithm, as once men surrendered rights to the Sovereign

Of the Nature of Selfies and Digital Vanity
Concerning the endless pursuit of digital self-portraiture
Of the constant need for validation through likes

Of the Nature of Memes and Digital Discourse
How complex ideas are reduced to simple images
Of the power of repetition in digital rhetoric

Of the End of This Discourse
Wherein final observations are made on digital society
Concerning hope for digital peace through common power

div.p: In this modern age, I have observed a most curious transformation of the state of nature. Where once men did war with swords and shields, they now do battle with likes and , and where once they did gather in market squares, they now do congregate in virtual spaces called social media, which are neither wholly social nor particularly media, but rather a strange amalgamation of both. In these digital realms, men do wage war not with steel but with emojis, and where once a man's worth was measured by the strength of his arm, it is now measured by the number of his followers, which are like unto the subjects of a digital kingdom, though they be but shadows on a screen. And yet, as I did write in my Leviathan, "the life of man is solitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short," though in this digital age, it is no longer solitary, for men are ever connected, yet paradoxically more alone than ever before, staring into their devices as if into the abyss of their own souls.

The state of nature, as I have previously demonstrated, is a war of all against all, where life is solitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short. Yet in this digital age, I do observe that the state of nature hath become a war of all against all on places like the one they name Twitter, where life is still and brutish, but no longer solitary, and certainly not short of words, though often short of sense. For in this new age, men do not fight for territory or resources, but for attention and validation, which are the new currencies of the digital commonwealth.
And lo, these battles do rage not in the physical realm, but in the ethereal space of the internet, where men do hurl insults and witticisms at one another with the speed of light, and where the victor is not he who doth wield the sharpest sword, but he who doth craft the most cutting tweet. Yet I must confess that in this digital state of nature, the life of man is still nasty and brutish, though it be conducted not in the wilderness, but in the comfort of one's own home, with a cup of tea and a device that doth connect one to the whole of the digital commonwealth.

div.head: Of the Nature of Posts and the Social Contract
div.p: In my time, men did write their thoughts upon parchment with quill and ink, taking great care in their composition. But in this digital age, men do compose their thoughts in 280 characters or fewer, and with such haste that they oft forget to consult their reason before pressing the button that doth send their words unto the world. And lo, these words do spread like wildfire, though oftentimes they are but the sparks of a mind that hath not been properly kindled.

The social contract in this new age hath become most curious. For whereas in my time, men did surrender their natural rights to a sovereign for the sake of peace and security, in this new age, men do surrender their privacy and dignity to the algorithm, that they might gain followers and likes, which are but the digital equivalent of the applause of the multitude. My dear friend Ren√© Descartes would surely postulate, "I post, therefore I am," though I fear he would be most perplexed by the notion that one's existence is now measured in likes and shares rather than in the certainty of thought.

div.head: Of the Nature of Selfies and Digital Vanity
div.p: In this new age, I have observed a most peculiar phenomenon: men and women do take pictures of themselves with their smartphones, which are like unto magic mirrors that do not speak the truth, but rather show what the user would have others believe. These self-portraits, or "selfies" as they are called, are oft accompanied by words of wisdom or wit, though more often than not they are but the empty vessels of vanity.

And lo, these selfies do multiply like rabbits in springtime, until the whole of the digital commonwealth is overrun with them, and men do spend their days not in contemplation of the divine, but in the contemplation of their own visages, filtered and enhanced beyond all recognition. John Locke would surely say that these digital portraits are but tabulae rasae, waiting to be inscribed with the vain fancies of their creators, though I fear he would be most disappointed to see how men have used their natural rights to pursue such trivial matters.

div.head: Of the Nature of Memes and Digital Discourse
div.p:
The learned men of this age do communicate not through reasoned argument, but through memes , which are like unto the hieroglyphs of ancient Egypt, but with less wisdom and more cats. These memes do spread through the digital commonwealth
with the speed of lightning, though they carry with them not the wisdom of the ages, but rather the fleeting humor of the moment.

And yet, I must confess that even I, Thomas Hobbes, have found myself chuckling at these digital hieroglyphs, though I know not why, for they are but the empty vessels of wit, filled with the wine of .

div.head: Of the End of This Discourse
div.p:
In conclusion, I must needs say that the digital commonwealth is a most curious place, where men do war with words instead of swords, and where the state of nature hath been transformed into a state of perpetual distraction. Yet I do remain hopeful, for as I have written, the passions that incline men to
peace are fear of death, desire of such things as are necessary to commodious living, and a hope by their industry to obtain them.

And though men do now seek these things through likes and shares instead of through the traditional means, the fundamental nature of man remaineth unchanged. For whether in the physical or digital realm, men do still seek peace, security, and the approval of their fellows, though they do now seek it through means most strange and wondrous.

note.p: The honourable Robert Boyle would surely say that these digital vapors are more volatile than his air pump experiments, and that the pressure of social media doth create a vacuum of reason in men's minds.
Twitter, a modern form of communication wherein men do express their thoughts in brief messages, limited to 280 characters, and which doth spread through the Commonwealth with the speed of lightning.

Verily, in the year of our Lord 2022, this platform did fall into the hands of one man of great wealth and greater ambition, who did rename it X, though none did call it so. Under his rule, the platform did become a most curious place, where the blue checkmark, once a mark of verification, did become a mark of subscription, and where the algorithm did favor the musings of the wealthy over the wisdom of the learned. And lo, the platform did lose much of its former glory, though it still doth persist, like a ghost of its former self, haunting the digital commonwealth.
Algorithm, a most curious device of the modern age, which doth determine what men shall see and hear, and which doth shape their understanding of the world in ways most mysterious.
Meme, a digital hieroglyph of the modern age, which doth spread through the Commonwealth with the speed of thought, though often with less substance than a puff of wind.
